title: 103_hr3160
content: The Act is titled the "Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act Technical Amendments of 1993" and includes amendments to the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended in various sections, including redesignating subsections and making changes to appointment terms. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to change appointment terms to a 3-year term and make adjustments to subsections in section 223. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to adjust subsections in section 223, including changes to appointment terms to a 3-year term. Amendments are made to various sections such as 241(d)(2) and 243(a) for clarity and consistency. The text chunk involves amendments to various sections of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974, including redesignating paragraphs, inserting commas, and making corrections for clarity and consistency. Amendments to the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 include adding programs for parents, targeting juveniles in contact with the justice system, and considering the needs of families with limited-English proficiency. Amendments to the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 include adding programs for parents, targeting juveniles in contact with the justice system, and considering the needs of families with limited-English proficiency. Changes to specific sections of the Act involve adding community service personnel, correcting the term "substances analogues" to "substance analogues," and inserting a new section before section 282 in subpart II of part D. The amendments include adding programs for parents and targeting juveniles in contact with the justice system. Additionally, there is a new section inserted before section 282 regarding the authority to call and conduct conferences. The amendments involve changes to various sections, such as extending the time frame to 48 months, redesignating parts, and adjusting language in different paragraphs. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the date of enactment, with a special effective date for specific amendments on November 4, 1992.
